greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle whose rows are sequences of increasing and decreasing tetrahedral numbers: 1; 1,4,1; 1,4,10,4,1; ... .
comment: Reading the triangle by rows produces the sequence 1,1,4,1,1,4,10,4,1,..., analogous to A004737.
T(n,k) = min(n*(n+1)*(n+2)/6,k*(k+1)*(k+2)/6) n, k >0. The order of the list T(n,k) is by sides of squares from T(1,n) to T(n,n), then from T(n,n) to T(n,1). - _Boris Putievskiy_, Jan 13 2013
link: Harvey P. Dale, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Boris Putievskiy, Transformations Integer Sequences And Pairing Functions arXiv:1212.2732 [math.CO]
formula: a(n) = z*(z+1)*(z+2)/6, where z = floor(sqrt(n-1)) - |n- floor(sqrt(n-1))^2- floor(sqrt(n-1))-1| +1. (End)
example: The start of the sequence as table:
The start of the sequence as triangle array read by rows:
mathematica: Module[{nn=10,tet},tet=Table[(n(n+1)(n+2))/6,{n,nn}];Table[Join[Take[ tet,k], Reverse[ Take[tet,k-1]]],{k,nn}]]//Flatten (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Oct 22 2017 *)
results.author: _Peter Bala_, Sep 25 2007
